question: In an electrical circuit the reverse current cut-out relay will open:

choices.choice: when battery voltage exceeds generator voltage.
when circuit voltage is less than generator voltage.
when the main output C/B is reset.

subject: Technical

question: A generator cut-out is provided:

choices.choice: to prevent the battery over heating.
to prevent the battery from being overcharged.
to allow the generator to be isolated in a crash.
to prevent discharge of the battery through the generator.

subject: Technical

question: A generator cut-out will open when:

choices.choice: circuit loads equal the battery voltage.
circuit loads equal the generator voltage.
generator voltage falls below battery voltage.

subject: Technical

question: A generator cut-out is fitted to prevent:

choices.choice: the battery discharging through the generator windings.
fire in the event of overloading the system.

subject: Technical

question: In the event of the cut-out points sticking in the closed position, the most probable results, when the engine stopped would be:
subject: Technical

question: To prevent circulating currents when more than one generator is being connected to the same bus bar:

choices.choice: the generators are connected in series.

subject: Technical

question: A generator cut-out is fitted:

choices.choice: in series with the generator output.
in parallel with the generator output.

subject: Technical

question: On a 28 volt system with a 24 volt battery the cut-out contacts close at approximately:

question: A component whose job is similar to a generator cut out is:

question: If the cut-out is open, the battery is feeding the loads which are:

question: In a two engine aircraft with two generators, there would be:

choices.choice: one ammeter for each generator and one voltmeter switchable to indicate either generator voltage or battery voltage.
one voltmeter for each generator. and one ammeter switchable to indicate either generator current or battery current.
one ammeter showing the total output and one switchable voltmeter .
one ammeter and one voltmeter each showing the average current and voltage output.

subject: Technical

question: A generator converts mechanical energy to electrical by:
subject: Technical

question: In an aircraft electrical system which incorporates a voltmeter, the voltmeter indicates:

choices.choice: the flow in the electrical system before the battery cut-out contacts close.
the rate of flow at all times.
the pressure in the electrical system before and after the cut-out contacts close.
the flow in the electrical system after the battery cut-out contacts close.

subject: Technical

question: If the generator warning light comes on in flight it indicates that:

choices.choice: the generator is feeding the battery bus bar.
the generator is not feeding the battery bus bar.

subject: Technical

question: A generator failure is usually indicated by:

choices.choice: the ammeter reading decreasing or showing a discharge and a red warning lamp lighting.
the voltmeter reading increasing, the ammeter reading showing discharge and a red lamp lighting.
the current consuming devices failing to operate.

subject: Technical

question: A generator warning light will be illuminated:

choices.choice: when the battery voltage exceeds that of the generator and the cut-out has opened.
when the generator is supplying current to a fully charged battery, and no electrical loads are switched on.
when the battery charge current is lower than required to maintain its fully charged state.

subject: Technical

question: If a generator fails in flight:

choices.choice: the watt metre will show a increase.

subject: Technical

question: If one generator fails you should:

choices.choice: stop and feather the engine concerned.
switch off the failed generator and continue normal use of the electrical system.
switch off the failed generator, and cut down on the electrical services being used.

subject: Technical

question: A generator is brought ‘on the line’ when it is:

choices.choice: connected in series with other generators.
switched into the electrical circuit in parallel with the other generators.
connected with the ground batteries for starting.

subject: Technical

question: In a twin engine aircraft, fitted with two generators, if one should fail:

choices.choice: the failed generator must be isolated.
cut down the air supply to reduce five risks.
the failed generator must be stopped.
both generators must be switched off.

subject: Technical

question: A generator is brought ‘on line’ via the battery cut-out by an increase in:
subject: Technical

question: Generator failure is indicted by:

choices.choice: a decrease or discharge in ammeter readings and generator warning light on.
an increase in voltmeter readings, a discharge in ammeter reading and generator warning light on.

subject: Technical

question: In a twin engine aircraft, with a generator fitted to both engines, the starboard generator fails. Will:

choices.choice: the engine with the failed generator will automatically feather.

subject: Technical

question: Loads on a bus bar are:

choices.choice: in series with the generator so that the voltage can be reduced.
in parallel so the voltage can be varied.
in parallel so the current can be reduced.
determined by the cross sectional area of the lead cable.

subject: Technical

subject: Technical

question: If the ammeter reads plus 5 amp after engine shut down:

question: If the ammeter shows ‘no’ charge, yet the battery remains charged. Would you look for:

question: During flight a malfunction of the generator cut-out would be indicated by:
subject: Technical

question: A short circuit in a “single pole” electrical circuit would be caused:

choices.choice: by a broken conductor between the source of supply and an item of equipment.
by an open circuit between loads in parallel.
when wiring between the source of supply and an item of equipment goes down to earth.
by an open circuit between an item of equipment and earth.

subject: Technical

question: In a “2 pole” electrical circuit, a short of the conductors would result in:

choices.choice: an item of equipment operating automatically without switches.
an item of equipment burning out because of a large current flow.

subject: Technical

question: The indicating range of an ammeter can be increased by fitting;

choices.choice: A shunt fitted in parallel with the instrument.
A shunt fitted in parallel with the load
A shunt fitted in series with the instrument
A multiplier fitted in parallel with the instrument

subject: Technical

question: An electrical system which uses the aircraft structure as a return path for current, is known as:
subject: Technical

question: On a single pole circuit, if the positive conductor is shorted to the aircraft structure:

choices.choice: the circuit will be under loaded.
the load will only operate at half speed.

subject: Technical

question: In a double pole circuit:

choices.choice: the current is supplied by one wire and the current is returned through the aircraft bonding system.
the current passes out through one wire and is returned through a second wire.
the current passes out through one wire and is returned via the aircraft’s immune circuit.

subject: Technical

question: In a earth return circuit if the conductor is open circuited:
subject: Technical

question: A ‘hot bus’ is:

choices.choice: the bus bar always connected to the battery
the bus bar that supplies the galley power
the bus bar that supplies the essential loads
the bus bar that supplies the nom-essential loads

subject: Technical

question: The earth return system of aircraft wiring is that:

choices.choice: one lead from the battery and one lead from the component is connected to the aircraft structure.
one lead from the battery is earthed and both leads of the components are earthed.
the negative sides of the system are connected direct to the positive side of the battery.

subject: Technical

question: A dipole circuit is one where:

choices.choice: the aircraft structure is used for the earth return.

subject: Technical
